dt: {bc}to come or gain admission into a group {bc}{sx|join||}
{bc}to go upon land for the purpose of taking possession
usually used in the subjunctive as a stage direction
{bc}to come into a preestablished situation or context like an actor coming onstage

dt.t: {wi}enter{/wi} the new principal with her radical ideas
other considerations {wi}enter{/wi} when money is involved

dt: {bc}to cause to be received or admitted

dt.t: {wi}enter{/wi} the new data into the computer

dt: {bc}to go into (a particular period of time)
{bc}to become a member of or an active participant in
{bc}to make report of (a ship or its cargo) to customs authorities
{bc}to place in proper form before a court of law or upon record
{bc}to go into or upon and take actual possession of (something, such as land)
{bc}to make oneself a party to or in

dt.t: {it}enter into{/it} the spirit of the occasion

dt: {bc}to engage in a fight or struggle

pt: {sc}enter{/sc} {sc}penetrate{/sc} {sc}pierce{/sc} {sc}probe{/sc} mean to make way into something. {sc}enter{/sc} is the most general of these and may imply either going in or forcing a way in.
{sc}penetrate{/sc} carries a strong implication of an impelling force or compelling power that achieves entrance.
{sc}pierce{/sc} means an entering or cutting through with a sharp pointed instrument.
{sc}probe{/sc} implies penetration to investigate or explore something hidden from sight or knowledge.

et: Middle English {it}entren{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}entrer{/it}, from Latin {it}intrare{/it}, from {it}intra{/it} within; akin to Latin {it}inter{/it} between {ma}{mat|inter-|}{/ma}
shortdef: to come or gain admission into a group : join —often used with into
